results.title: Patterns
results.brief_description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. A number of threads are woven between the sweatshop and the art gallery, the glory box and the political banner, bourgeois femininity and the question: should a feminist knit? An incisive and kaleidoscopic exploration of needlework and its place in women’s lives.
results.description: Patterns is a documentary which explores issues to do with politics, work, art and women’s history. results.title: Pattern, purpose and prospect
results.brief_description: This British documentary promotes the benefits to industry of new computing technology. A prescient film; as well as arguing the necessity of adapting computers to commercial and industrial applications, it anticipates the ubiquity of digital technology in the years to follow. This film is part of the epicentre of a high-nerd aesthetic of colourfully geeky enthusiasm for cheesy electronic technology.

results.title: Pattern of life
results.creator_credit: Collings Productions, Dahl Collings and Geoffrey Collings
results.brief_description: Bark painting - inseparable from the social, cultural and religious life of the Australian Aborigine - shown as it is today to satisfy the demands of a commercial market and as it was, the changing pattern of the life of the Aborigine being reflected in his painting. Illustrations in Arnhem Land range from the fishing and hunting, musicians and dancing, to fighting, and mourning and burial ceremonies. In its western region we see various animal and plant totems in the attractive “x-ray” style, whilst elsewhere wind designs, clusters of stars, cycad and hybiscus trees are depicted.

results.title: Pattern of Britain: north east corner
results.creator_credit: Green Park Productions, Ralph Keene and John Eldridge
results.brief_description: A study of the communities in the extreme north-west area of Scotland, which, once dependent on fishing for their livelihood, are today becoming increasingly dependent on agriculture. Features the area’s main city of Aberdeen. The story is told by an old fisherman.

results.title: Pattern interpretation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sewing”.
Discusses such problems as the interpretation of markings on various well-known commercial patterns; how to determine pattern size, yardage required, and the interpretation of pattern instructions.

results.title: Pattern for progress
results.brief_description: The pilot project conducted in the Yass River Valley, to investigate the difference between the current methods of land use and the agricultural potential of the area. Describes the work of the extension officers of the Department of Agriculture in bridging the gap between the knowledge gained by research scientists and its practical application by farmers to the problems of increasing production. Investigations into soil fertility, water supply, farm economics and other factors have made much valuable information available to Yass Valley farmers.

results.title: Pattern for instruction
results.creator_credit: Roundtable Productions, Leon S. Gold and Jack Denove

results.title: Pattern for chemicals
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Denis Segaller
results.brief_description: An introduction to the use of refinery gases, as derived from the ‘cracking’ proccesses, as raw material for a new chemical industry. From the cracked gas molecules and others, the chemist and the chemical engineer have learned to fashion and construct in new ways the molecules of a great many useful substances.

results.title: Patsy Comes To Stay
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a silent comedy narrative entitled ‘Patsy Comes to Stay’, which was produced by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society. The film was directed by H.J.D. Law and features Rankine as the Chief of Police.

results.title: Patsy Adam-Smith: author and social historian
results.creator_credit: Janet McLeod, Catherine South and Women's Program of the AFC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian women’s archival Series”.
An archival interview in which Patsy tells of her childhood, the inspirations for her books, her philosophy on oral history, her working methods, the adventure of her life at sea and her thoughts on love, children and marriage. Most of her books focus on the lives of ‘ordinary’ Australian working people, uncovering the unique history, folklore and lifestyle - the ‘real’ history of Australia, often lost in the overview of traditional history. Tagged as an ‘unconventional woman’, Patsy ignored the social rules of her day, and blithely worked in, sought out and wrote about the worlds in which women traditionally had no place.
